rationale: The Porbeagle (Lamna nasus) is a large (to 357 cm total length) pelagic shark with an anti-tropical and disjunct distribution, occurring in the North Atlantic and Southern Hemisphere in temperate and cold-temperate waters to depths of 1,809 m. There are two separate subpopulations, the North Atlantic and the Southern Hemisphere. The species has low biological productivity with small litters, late age-at-maturity, and a shorter life span of 26 years in the North Atlantic compared to 60 years in the Southern Hemisphere. Globally, the species is targeted and caught incidentally in coastal and pelagic commercial and small-scale longline, purse seine, and gillnet fisheries, as well as by rod and reel, and is often retained for the high-value meat as well as its fins. Steep declines have occurred in the North Atlantic; with declines also evident, though not as steep, in the Southern Hemisphere. The North Atlantic subpopulation reduction was 50–79% over three generations (58.5 years) and the Southern Hemisphere subpopulation reduction was <20% over three generations (114.9 years). The overall estimated median reduction was 26.5%, with a 41.5% probability of <20% reduction and 45.5% probability of >30% reduction over three generations. Expert judgement elicitation was used to estimate that globally, the reduction is 30–49% over three generations (58.5 and 114.9 years) and therefore, the Porbeagle is assessed globally as Vulnerable A2bd.
habitat: The Porbeagle occurs inshore and over continental shelves, shelf edges, offshore banks, and in the open ocean to depths of 1,809 m (Francis et al. 2008, Reyes and Torres-Florez 2009, Weigmann 2016). It prefers cold, temperate waters below 18°C (Campana and Joyce 2004, Francis et al. 2008, Skomal et al. 2009). It reaches a maximum size of 357 cm total length (TL), though maximum size is likely larger in the North Atlantic as individuals >230 cm TL are rare in the Southwest Pacific (Francis et al. 2008). Males mature at 140–165 cm TL in the Southern Hemisphere and 155–177 cm TL in the North Atlantic, females mature at about 170–195 cm TL in the Southern Hemisphere and 200–219 cm TL in the North Atlantic (Jensen et al. 2002, Natanson et al. 2002, Francis and Duffy 2005, Francis et al. 2008, Forselledo 2012). Reproduction is aplacental viviparous and oophagous with litters of 1–5 (usually 4), with a 8–9 month gestation period, an annual, but possibly biennial, reproductive cycle, and size at birth of 68–78 cm TL (Francis and Stevens 2000, Francis et al. 2008, Ebert et al. 2013). Regional differences in bomb radiocarbon validated age estimates are apparent from the Northwest Atlantic and Southwest Pacific. Female age at maturity is 13 and 16.5 years and maximum age is 26 and 60 years; generation length is therefore 19.5 and 38.3 years, respectively (Campana et al. 2002, Francis et al. 2007, Francis 2015). Population growth rate is low but is countered by high juvenile survival rates to produce an overall moderate population growth rate in the North Atlantic of 0.052–0.081 (Dulvy et al. 2008, Cortés et al. 2015).
threats:
The Porbeagle is caught globally as target and bycatch in commercial and small-scale pelagic longline, purse seine, and gillnet fisheries. Most of the catch is taken as bycatch of large-scale pelagic fleets in offshore and high-seas waters. It may also be captured in coastal longlines, gillnets, trammel nets and sometimes trawls, as well as on rod on reel, particularly in areas with narrow continental shelves (Camhi et al. 2008). The Northeast Atlantic stock has the longest history of commercial exploitation with the highest catches during the 1930s and 1950s (ICCAT 2010).

Porbeagles are often retained for their meat and fins (Clarke et al. 2006a, Clarke et al. 2006b, Dent and Clarke 2015, Fields et al. 2018), although fishing and/or retention is prohibited in some areas. Under-reporting of catches in the pelagic and domestic fisheries is likely (Dent and Clarke 2015). The species is highly valued by recreational fishers, and although many practice catch and release, recreational fishing could be a threat due to post-release mortality (Camhi et al. 2008). The post-release mortality on commercial longlines has been reported as 10–75% (Campana et al. 2016).
population:
There are no data available on the absolute global population size of the Porbeagle. Genetic data support two separate subpopulations of the Porbeagle, the North Atlantic and the Southern Hemisphere (Kitamura and Matsunaga 2010, Testerman 2014). No genetic structure was found within the North Atlantic or Southern Hemisphere subpopulations (Testerman 2014).

Population trend data are available from four stock assessments: (1) Northwest Atlantic (ICCAT 2010); (2) Canadian Northwest Atlantic (Campana et al. 2013); (3) Northeast Atlantic (ICCAT 2010); and, (4) Southern Hemisphere risk assessment (Hoyle et al. 2017). The trend data from each source were analyzed over three generation lengths using a Bayesian state-space framework (a modification of Winker et al. 2018). This analysis yields an annual rate of change, a median change over three generation lengths, and the probability of the most likely IUCN Red List category percent change over three generations (see the Supplementary Information).

First, the Northwest Atlantic stock assessment bycatch surplus production (BSP) model indicated that in 2009 the biomass was 37% of that in 1961, but that with the currently low fishing mortality and an apparent increase in biomass in recent years, the stock is slowly recovering, although recovery could take decades due to the low productivity of Porbeagle (ICCAT 2010). The trend analysis of the biomass for 1961–2009 (49 years) revealed annual rates of reduction of 1.8%, consistent with a median reduction of 65.2% over three generation lengths (58.5 years), with the highest probability of 50–79% reduction over three generation lengths.

Second, the Canadian Northwest Atlantic stock assessment age-structured model indicated that the 2009 biomass was 22–27% of that in 1962, but that in recent years reduced quotas have halted the decline and the number of mature females is increasing (Campana et al. 2013, Curtis et al. 2016). The trend analysis of the Canadian biomass for 1962–2009 (48 years) revealed steep annual rates of reduction of 4.2%, consistent with a median reduction of 90.7% over three generation lengths (58.5 years), with the highest probability of >80% reduction over three generation lengths. Both Northwest Atlantic stock assessments have led to the conclusion that the Porbeagle stock is overfished but overfishing is currently not occurring (SCRS 2014, Curtis et al. 2016).

Third, the Northeast Atlantic stock assessment estimated that the 2009 biomass was 6% of unexploited biomass, although this estimate is uncertain, and that the stock is overfished but overfishing is not occurring (ICCAT 2010). Since 2010, the Total Allowable Catch in the Northeast Atlantic has been set to zero and since converted to a prohibition, to help the stock recover (SCRS 2014). The trend analysis of the biomass for 1926–2009 (84 years) revealed annual rates of reduction of 1.8%, consistent with a median reduction of 56.5% over three generation lengths (58.5 years), with the highest probability of 50–79% reduction over three generation lengths.

Fourth, the risk assessment model of the Southern Hemisphere population indicated that fishing mortality is low, decreasing eastward from South Africa to New Zealand, and that there is a very low risk the population is subject to overfishing (Hoyle et al. 2017). Catch rate indicators showed stable or increasing catches across most of the Southern Hemisphere (Hoyle et al. 2017). The trend analysis of the modeled relative abundance for 1962–2015 (54 years) revealed modest annual rates of reduction of 0.2%, consistent with a median reduction of 19.9% over three generation lengths (114.9 years), with the highest probability of <20% reduction over three generation lengths.

Across both subpopulations, the Porbeagle was estimated to have strongly declined in the North Atlantic and to have declined, but to a far less degree, in the Southern Hemisphere. The North Atlantic subpopulation reduction was 50–79% over three generations (58.5 years) and the Southern Hemisphere subpopulation reduction was <20% over three generations (114.9 years). To estimate a global population trend, the estimated three generation population trends for each region were weighted according to the relative size of each region; the two sources of Northwest Atlantic data were used to generate two global trends. The overall estimated median reduction was 26.5%, with the highest probability of <20% reduction over three generations. However, this global trend was strongly influenced by the Southern Hemisphere trend, as this accounts for a larger proportion of the global distribution. Expert judgement elicitation was used to estimate that globally, the reduction is 30–49% over three generations (58.5 and 114.9 years) and therefore, the Porbeagle is assessed globally as Vulnerable A2bd.
range: The Porbeagle has an anti-tropical and disjunct distribution, occurring in the North Atlantic and Southern Hemisphere in temperate and cold-temperate waters (Ebert et al. 2013). Porbeagles do not occur in the North Pacific, where they are replaced by the congener, the Salmon Shark (Lamna ditropis) (Francis et al. 2008).
useTrade: The Porbeagle is used for its fins, liver oil, and high-quality meat (Francis et al. 2008, Hernandez et al. 2008). Together with the Salmon Shark, the two species accounted for 0.2% of the fin imported in Hong Kong in 2014 (Fields et al. 2018). In some counties, such as Spain, Porbeagle meat accounts for a significant proportion, at 15%, of all shark meat imported annually (Dent and Clarke 2015).
conservationActions:
The success of actions agreed through international wildlife and fisheries treaties depends on implementation at the domestic level; for sharks, such follow up actions have to date been seriously lacking.

In 2008, the Porbeagle was listed on Appendix II of the Convention on Migratory Species (CMS), which reflects Parties’ commitments to work regionally toward conservation. The species is also covered by the CMS Memorandum of Understanding for Migratory Sharks, which is aimed at facilitating conservation. In 2013, the Porbeagle was added to Appendix II of the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species (CITES), which requires CITES Parties to ensure that exports be accompanied by permits based on findings that parts are sourced from legal and sustainable fisheries.

In 2010, the North-East Atlantic Fisheries Commission (NEAFC) adopted a ban on directed fishing for Porbeagle that has since been renewed several times. The current (2016) measure runs through 2019 and applies to the NEAFC Regulatory Area (high seas). The Western and Central Pacific Fisheries Commission (WCPFC) designated the Porbeagle as a “Key Shark Species” in 2010, but has yet to set Porbeagle fishing limits. In 2012, the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (GFCM) banned retention and mandated careful release for the Porbeagle and 23 other elasmobranch species listed on the Barcelona Convention Annex II. Implementation by GFCM Parties, however, has been very slow. In 2015, to address depletion in the North Atlantic, the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT) adopted a requirement for prompt, careful release of Porbeagles retrieved alive in ICCAT-managed fisheries. ICCAT also pledged to consider additional measures if future Porbeagle catches exceed 2014 levels.

To prevent overfishing and allow recovery, it is recommended that Porbeagles be subject to regional and national catch limits based on scientific advice and/or the precautionary approach, as well as improved reporting of catch data (including discards), efforts to minimize bycatch mortality, and full implementation of all commitments agreed through international treaties.

rationale: Helcogrammoides antarcticus is only known from a few specimens collected in Antarctica. Nothing is known about H. antarcticus distribution, population, habitat, or ecology. Climate change impacts may be important threats H. antarcticus in this region. Therefore, H. antarcticus is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: The habitat preference for Helcogrammoides antarcticus is unknown.
threats: It is not known if there are any threats to Helcogrammoides antarcticus. Climate change impacts may be important in this region.
population: There is no population information available for Helcogrammoides antarcticus and is only known a few specimens (Williams pers.comm. 2010).
range: Helcogrammoides antarcticus is known only from the type locality, Paradise Bay, Antarctic Peninsula (Williams and Springer 2001).
useTrade: There is no use/trade information for Helcogrammoides antarcticus.
conservationActions: Helcogrammoides antarcticus is not known to occur in any marine protected areas.

rationale: This species has a relatively small range on the continental shelf and slope of the southern part of the Patagonia Sea where it plays an important ecological role as a prey item for larger marine species. The majority of its global population is concentrated in southern Argentina, including the Malvinas Islands, where the main fishing ground is located. One generation length is estimated as 10 years. It is relatively slow-growing and late to maturity with relatively low fecundity, which may cause it to be susceptible to declines when facing heavy fishing pressure. Previous to 2006, it was mostly discarded as bycatch in large quantities beginning in the 1980s. A large-scale, commercial fishery began in 2007 in the Malvinas area. In areas outside the Malvinas closer to the Argentine mainland, it is taken in fisheries in relatively small amounts. According to stock assessment models based on catch per unit effort data and fishery independent trawl surveys, the estimated biomass for the period of 2005 to 2018 was highest in 2005 and then declined by 79% to a low in 2018. According to the 2019 and 2020 survey results, biomass has continued to decline. Biomass trends prior to 2005 are poorly understood, but based on these data, it is suspected that its population has declined by 40-50% on a global-level over the past one and a half generation lengths, or 15 years. In addition, declines in length at maturity and average length of individuals in the survey catch have also occurred. The cause of decline is poorly understood, but may be attributed in part to fishing activity or a shift in the spatial distribution of its abundance to areas adjacent to the Malvinas. Several fishery management measures are in place, catches have been at a relatively low level and it is not considered overfished. Due to the uncertainty associated with the cause of decline and lack of data prior to 2005, it is not possible to estimate the population trend to cover a three generation length period (either in the past or into the future) at this time. It is listed as Data Deficient with a strong recommendation to conduct studies to improve the understanding of this decline both within the Malvinas area and areas adjacent to it.
habitat: This benthopelagic species inhabits the continental shelf and slope on both sandy and rocky areas. It plays an important ecological role as a prey item to many larger fish predators (Laptikhovsky et al. 2013). According to fecundity studies by Brickle et al. (2006), fertility is relatively low (J.M. Díaz de Astarloa pers. comm. 2019). The maximum total length is 41 cm. Spawning occurs on the continental shelf break. Longevity is 14 years and length and age at first maturity is 27.6 cm for males and 24.8 cm for females and approximately 5 years (Brickle et al. 2006). When applying an age at first reproduction of 5 years and longevity of 14 years, its estimated generation length is 10 years based on the following equation recommended by the IUCN Red List methods: Age at first reproduction + (Age at last reproduction – age at first reproduction)/2.
threats: Overfishing is a potential major threat. This species is relatively slow growing and late to maturity with relatively low fecundity, which may cause it to be susceptible to declines when facing heavy fishing pressure.
population:
This species is common and abundant off southern Argentina, but less common off Chile. It has a particularly high abundance in the Namuncurá Burwood Bank Marine Protected Area Plateau (J.M. Díaz de Astarloa pers. comm. 2020). The main fishing ground for this species is located in the Malvinas area, and is taken in relatively small amounts in areas closer to the Argentine mainland. Fishing fleets that operate in international waters off Argentina also take this species. It is not targeted by fisheries in the Pacific part of its range nor in the northern part of the Atlantic range (Uruguay) as it is less common in those areas (C. Buratti, J.M. Díaz de Astarloa and M. Hüne pers. comm. 2019). 

The Malvinas stock of Southern Blue Whiting (Micromesistius australis) collapsed in 2004-2007 primarily due to overfishing, and following this, the catches and catch per unit effort of this species (Rock Cod) increased by 20-30 fold between 2002-2004 and 2009-2011 (Laptikhovsky et al. 2013). Large amounts of landings of this species were taken by the fisheries operating on the shelf and slope of the Malvinas between 2006 to 2015. Catch peaked in 2010 at 76,451 t and declined thereafter with a particularly steep decline occurring after 2015 to a low of 2,213 t in 2018. Since the fishery began in 2007, catch per unit effort increased until 2010 before declining thereafter. However, effort has been difficult to estimate as this species is not always the main target and has a patchy distribution that varies annually in the area. Vessels may choose to target Hake and/or Kingclip as they have a higher market value than this species.

Abundances estimates have not been made in any region other than the Malvinas Islands (C. Buratti pers. comm. 2020). Fishery independent scientific trawl surveys have been conducted throughout the Malvinas area since 2010, but were not carried out in the years 2012-2014. The mean length of individuals of this species captured in these surveys declined over time from 22 cm in 2010 to 18 cm in 2020. Length at maturity also declined from 2003 to 2018. These declines are inferred to be caused by fishing pressure (Winter 2019). Survey biomass peaked in 2011 at 1,090,655 t and then declined by 98% to a low of 22,335 t in 2020, or over one past generation length (Ramos and Winter 2020). Modelled biomass has been estimated for the time period from 2005 to 2018. Biomass was highest in 2005 at about 1,250,000 t and mostly declined thereafter to about 265,000 t in 2018, which represents a 79% decline over the past one and a half generation lengths, or 15 years. Biomass trends of this species prior to 2005 are poorly understood. The most recent stock assessment concluded that the stock is not overfished and overfishing is not occurring, but recognized there has been an 8-fold decline in the stock since at least 2005. Despite the situation that fishery catches have been at a relatively low level, no recovery in the stock has been detected (Winter 2019). The continuing decline in biomass may be due to changes in its distribution, but in general, the cause appears to be poorly understood (Ramos and Winter 2020).
range: This species is distributed in the southeastern Pacific from Isla Madre de Dios, Chile (about 50°S) to Cape Horn and in the southwestern Atlantic from Argentina to Uruguay, including the Malvinas Islands and Burdwood Bank at 55°S (Brickle et al. 2005, Irigoyen et al. 2018). It has also been recorded in the South Georgia Islands and off the eastern tip of the Antarctic Peninsula (iDigBio database accessed May 2020). The depth range is 50-500 metres.
useTrade: This species is targeted and sold for human consumption in Tierra del Fuego and the Malvinas Islands. Since the 1980s, it has comprised a large proportion of the bycatch in squid and finfish trawl fisheries (La Mesa et al. 2016). Previous to 2006, it was typically discarded due to its low commercial value (Laptikhovsky and Arkhipkin 2003, Brickle et al. 2006), but is now directly targeted by commercial fisheries operating on the shelf off the Malvinas (Arkhipkin et al. 2013).
conservationActions: Fishing effort is regulated through an Individual Transferable Quota (ITQ) licensing system, total allowable catch limits, seasonal and area closures and gear restrictions. It occurs in a permanent closed area for the Argentine hake fishery on the Argentine continental shelf around 45°S (Alemany et al. 2013) and in the Namuncurá Burwood Bank Marine Protected Area Plateau (J.M. Díaz de Astarloa pers. comm. 2020). Improvements in fisheries management are needed to address biomass declines.

rationale: Bathydraco joannae has been assessed as Least Concern. Due to the deep-water nature of this species it is unlikely to be threatened by any significant human-induced or climatic threat. However, further research is needed to determine if this species and B. antarcticus are in fact synonymous but it is unlikely that the conservation status assigned would change even if the taxonomy did.
habitat: This bathydemersal species is most commonly found on the upper continental slope at depths ranging from 600 - 1,800 m. While there is no available information on the feeding ecology of this species, congeners such as Bathydraco marri have been observed to feed upon mysids, amphipods and copepods, along with euphausiids, isopods and tanaids (Mesa et al. 2007).
threats: Due to the deepwater nature of this species it is unlikely that Bathydraco joannae is being impacted upon by any major threat processes. It may be taken incidentally as a by-catch species by fisheries operating within its range.
population: There is no population information available for Bethydraco joannae.
range: Bathydraco joannae is found to occur on the upper slopes of the Scotia Sea Islands, Patagonian Slope, close to the Falkland Islands, and off the Kerguelen Islands.
conservationActions:
There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for Bathydraco joannae.

Further research is needed on the taxonomy of this species to determine if it is synonymous with Bathydraco antarcticus.

rationale: Akarotaxis nudiceps has been assessed as Least Concern. Due to the deep-water nature and remote but widespread geographic distribution of this species, it is unlikely that it is being threatened by any climatic or human-induced threat processes. A. nudiceps is also known to be a dominant species in areas of its broad distribution around the Southern Ocean.
habitat: Akarotaxis nudiceps is bathydemersal and lives at temperatures as low as -1.65° Celsius. This species has a depth range of 371-915 m and can be found on the outer shelf and deep in troughs. This species has the lowest fecundity of any known bathydraconid species, producing only 2000 eggs per female (La Mesa et al. 2007). Spawning may occur from mid to late summer (Gon 1990).
threats: Due to the deepwater nature of this species it is unlikely that Akarotaxis nudiceps is being impacted upon by any major threat processes. It may be taken incidentally as a by-catch species.
population: Akarotaxis nudiceps has been described as the dominant species in the Gould Bay area (Ekau 1990). This species comprised 3.2% of the catch from a bottom trawl in the Ross Sea (Eastman and Hubold 1999).
range: Akarotaxis nudiceps has a near circumantarctic distribution from west of the Adelaide Islands round to the Ross Sea.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place or that are needed for Akarotaxis nudiceps.

rationale: Pleuragramma antarctica has been assessed as Least Concern. This species has no major threats acting against it at present, and it has been reported to be the most dominant pelagic fish species in areas of its broad distribution. Because this species plays an important role in the Antarctic ecosystem food web, continued monitoring of the population numbers is needed. It is not commercially harvested.
habitat:
Pleuragramma antarctica is regarded as the only truly pelagic fish species in Antarctic waters. Specimens have been collected over mud and sandy mud bottoms, however the morphometrics of this species indicates that it does not feed on the benthos. This species has a depth range of 0-728 m, with the larvae and postlarvae occurring at a depth range of 0-135 m; juveniles at 50-400 m and adults are found at depths below 400 m. All of this vertical distribution is throughout the Antarctic continental shelf (O. Gon pers. comm. 2009).This species predominantly feeds on krill and copepods, however amphipods, euphausiids, molluscs, polychaetes, chaetognaths and ostracods are also part of its diet. Pleuragramma antarctica may also switch to cannibalism in the absence of an adequate food supply. This species inhabits both open waters and areas of pack ice in mid-water.

With its wide distribution and high numbers, P. antarctica forms a major part of the diet of most large Antarctic predators. This species is an important part of the cryopelagic feeding community (Hureau 1994). It is very slow growing and takes considerable time to reach maturity. Considering its importance, a significant decline in population numbers could have severe ecological ramifications.

Spawning possibly occurs in August-September (Kock and Kellermann 1991).
threats:
It is unlikely that any major threat is impacting P. antarctica. At present this species is not commercially exploited. The Former Soviet Union has reported catches of P. antarctica four times between 1977 and 1983 (approximately 1,000 t per year). Due to the prominent role of this species in the Antarctic ecosystem food web, any attempts to exploit this fish species in the future will be cautiously approached according to the CCAMLR (Convention for the Conservation of Antarctic Marine Living Resources) rules.

Larvae and juveniles are captured as by-catch in krill fisheries, but this is not considered a major threat (O. Gon pers. comm. 2009).
population: Pleuragramma antarctica is described as dominant in the Weddell Sea (Ekau 1990). Guglielmo et al. (1998) describe it as the most dominant pelagic fish in the high Antarctic. It represents about 98% of the total nototheniid ichthyoplankton of the Weddell Sea (Keller 1983). The overwhelming dominance of P. antarcticum is well documented in the Ross Sea and Weddell Sea, accounting for over 90% of the local fish community in number and biomass (DeWitt 1970, Hubold and Ekau 1987). Abundances of postlarvae reach as high as 27,075 specimens per 100 m3 in the Ross Sea.
range: Pleuragramma antarctica has a circumantarctic distribution which includes the Weddell Sea, Bellingshausen, Ross Sea, Davis Sea, Oates, Adelie, Wilhelm, Prydz Bay, Antarctic Peninsula, South Shetland and the South Orkney Islands.
useTrade: At present this species is not commercially exploited.
conservationActions:
There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for Pleuragramma antarctica, however the area in which this species is found is managed by CCAMLR. The convention was established due to concerns on increasing fishing pressure on krill and the impact this may pose to other marine organisms.

Monitoring of the population numbers of this species is needed.

rationale:
This species is widespread and common. Although this species is likely impacted by shallow-water bottom trawling within at least parts of its range, there is no indication of widespread population decline. Globally it is listed as Least Concern.

Only two specimens have been collected from Brazil, and bottom trawling is occurring throughout this species known depth and distribution range. However, more information is needed to determine this species distribution, population status, and impact of trawling within Brazil. In Brazil it therefore has a regional assessment of Data Deficient.
habitat:
This species is usually taken on muddy bottoms in shallow coastal waters at depths from 4-146 m. The Brazilian record is based on only two females, 250-292 mm, taken on the continental shelf at 30-45m depth (Mincarone and Soto 2001, Mincarone 2003). Of 86 specimens examined by Wisner and McMillan (1995), 71 (82%) were female, 12 (14%) male, and three (4%) hermaphroditic. Numbers and sizes of large eggs range from 9 (24 x 8 mm) in a female of 330 mm to 16 (21 x 7 mm) in one of 345 mm.

The biology of this species is unknown and its copulatory organ is absent. The gonads of hagfishes are situated in the peritoneal cavity. The ovary is found in the anterior portion of the gonad, and the testis is found in the posterior part. The animal becomes female if the cranial part of the gonad develops or male if the caudal part undergoes differentiation. If none develops, then the animal becomes sterile. If both anterior and posterior parts develop, then the animal becomes a functional hermaphrodite. However, hermaphroditism being characterised as functional needs to be validated by more reproduction studies (Patzner 1998).
threats: The species' distribution and habitat overlaps with an area that is extensively impacted by trawl fisheries.
population: This species is known to be common, particularly along the coast of Argentina. However there are no data to interpret population levels and rates of decline.
range: This species is located off the southern coast of South America, from southern Brazil (Rio Grande do Sul) to southern Chile (Golfo de Corcovado, Chiloé Island), including Tierra del Fuego and Strait of Magellan (Mincarone and Soto 2001). It was also reported from the South Shetland Islands based on a single 230 mm specimen (Norman 1937, Hureau and Fischer 1985, Fernholm 1990).
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place, but more research is needed on this species' biology, population size, distribution and impact of fisheries activities.

rationale: Alepocephalus australis is widely distributed in tropical and temperate waters around the globe. In the Eastern Central Atlantic, A. australis possibly occurs from the Gulf of Guinea to South Africa. This species is common and dominant in parts of its range. It inhabits sea-mounts and is found in depths from 600 m to 5,000 m. There are no major threats known and although there is potential for commercial fishery, there is no commercial utilization at present time. This species is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: Alepocephalus australis achieves sizes of up to 42 cm (standard length). The family is comprised of benthic to midwater fishes (600 to 5,000 m), with species most numerous below 1,000 m (Hartel in press). This species feeds on a variety of food items including shrimp, squid, fish, salps and holothurians (Parin et al. 2008).
threats: There are no major threats known for this species. In the Eastern Central Atlantic region trawl fisheries do not trawl deeper than 200 m (Nunoo pers. comm. 2012 and Koranteng 2001).
population: A survey of the composition and distribution of deepwater ichthyofauna of the Lord Howe Rise and Norfolk Ridge indicate that the family Alepocephalidae was one of the two important families in depths sampled from 1,000 m to1,500 m. This species occurred commonly and was one of the 25 most abundant taxa (biomass) in the survey (Zintzen et al. 2011). In a survey of the ichthyofauna of the Mozambique Seamount, this species was among the ten species with the greatest numbers and commercial prospect (Parin et al. 2008). It is well represented in museum collections with the bulk of the specimens collected from the Western Atlantic and southwest Pacific.
range: Alepocephalus australis can be found around the world in tropical and temperate waters, excluding the Indian Ocean, northwestern Pacific and eastern Pacific. In the Eastern Central Atlantic, A. australis possibly occurs from the Mauritania to South Africa, including Morocco and Western Sahara.
useTrade: At the present time, no commercial fishery exists for this species although it has been indicated that there is potential for commercial use in the future (Parin et al. 2008, Hartel in press).
conservationActions: There are no major threats known and although marine reserves overlap in parts of its distribution (World Database on Protected Areas 2010), it is unknown if the depths at which this species occurs are within the protection of these reserves.

rationale: Notolychnus valdiviae is a widespread, common species that is not facing any known threats. More research on this species needs to be conducted to assess the population size and trend in the eastern Atlantic. This species is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This species is oceanic, mesopelagic and performs diel migrations from as deep as 400-700 m during the day, up to 25-700 m during the night for feeding purposes. Spawning peaks in early summer (Hulley and Paxton in press).
threats: There are no known threats for this species, and it is not under pressure from fisheries.
population: This species appears to be fairly common in the eastern Atlantic (Kobylianksy et al. 2010), and it is also abundant in other parts of is range, such as the northern Sargasso Sea and the Gulf of Mexico (Gartner 1987, 1989). It is abundant in museum collection records.
range: This species is found throughout the eastern Atlantic, though it is absent from the Benguela upwelling region. It is also widespread in the rest of the Atlantic ocean from 56°N–52°S, in the Indian Ocean from 17°N–44°S, and in the Pacific from 45°N–40°S (Hulley and Paxton in press) but with 20°S southern limit in Peruvian Transitional Zone (Hulley 1990).
useTrade: This species in not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. Its distribution overlaps with some marine protected areas in parts of its range (World Database on Protected Species 2010).

rationale: This deep-water species is widespread, although its presence in the Eastern Central Atlantic needs investigation. It is not utilized and there are no known threats. Therefore, it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: An overall increase in average size with depth occurs with A. rostrata. Length at first sexual maturity in A. rostrata is 41-43 cm (Fossen and Bergstad 2006). However, as it matures in size and age, it tends to move off the coast and spawn in the deeper parts of its range (Paulin 1995). There is evidence that A. rostrata forms aggregations segregated at larger sizes by sex (Iwamoto 1975). The maximum size recorded is 42.75 cm (SL). This species is known to feed on benthic invertebrates (Paulin 1995).
threats: It is not utilized and there are no known threats to this species.
population:
Antimora rostrata is probably one of the most abundant fishes frequenting abyssal depths in the world's oceans. Females are predominate in catches and large males are uncommon (Iwamoto 1975). In depths between 1,000 and 1,500 m in Greenland the proportion of females increased to 55.6% (n = 692). In trawl hauls from the MAR similar numbers were 70.5% at depths between 1,000 and 2,000 m (n = 342) and 98.8% at depths exceeding 2,000 m (n = 181; Fossen and Bergstad 2006).

Within its peak depth range (1,200-2,700 m), A. rostrata is among the dominating species in all data sets in terms of population density (Fossen and Bergstad 2006).
range: Antimora rostrata appears to have a worldwide distribution. It occurs through the eastern and western Pacific south to Tasmania. It occurs in the Atlantic from the Davis Strait (64°N) south through the eastern and western Atlantic to the Antarctic Convergence off South Georgia. It also occurs in the southern Indian Ocean south into Antarctic waters to about 59°S (Iwamoto 1975). In the Eastern Central Atlantic, this species is commonly found from Gabon to the southern tip of South Africa. It is a bentho-pelagic species that inhabits depths between 350-3,000 m (Cohen et al. 1990), although it is most usually found between 1,300-2,500 m depths (Scott and Scott 1988). It resides on the continental slope and upper rise (Cohen 1986).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place for this species.

rationale: This species is known from the northern and southern temperate Atlantic,  as well as the southern Pacific. In western Africa, it is found from  Morocco south to Angola and the Cape Verde Islands. It is also found  from St. Helena. It has a depth range of 50-2,000 m. Additional  collecting in the central part of its range is required to establish its  presence there. This species is not utilized, and there are no major threats known to affect it. It is listed as Least Concern with a need for more research concerning its distribution and abundance, as well as habitat and ecology.
habitat: This is a temperate, pelagic species found from 50-2,000 m. It is primarily the larvae that occur in the shallower parts of this depth range. There is little information about its feeding habits, however, it likely feeds on pelagic fishes and crustaceans. It is also a food fish for other pelagic organisms.
threats: There are no major threats known to affect this species.
population: There are no population data available for this species.
range: This species is known from the northern and southern temperate Atlantic, as well as the southern Pacific. In western Africa, it is found from Morocco south to Angola and the Cape Verde Islands, although the north and south subpopulations are disjunct. It is also found from St. Helena. It has a depth range of 50-2,000 m. Additional collecting in the central part of its range is required to establish its presence there.
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place for the protection of this species.

rationale: This species is almost ubiquitously found throughout the Atlantic and the Pacific Oceans. It has an estimated depth distribution of zero to 5,000 m. It appears to be common. This species is not utilized and there are currently no known threats. Therefore, this species is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This is a pelagic species that dwells in waters at zero to 5,000 m. Juveniles generally occupy shallower parts of its depth distribution while adults venture deeper. It is consumed by many other large pelagic species, and itself feeds on small pelagic fishes and shrimps. In the tropical and sub-tropical region of its distribution it is known to spawn all year round (Muus and Nielsen 1999).
threats: There are no major threats known to affect this species.
population: Abundance and population data are unavailable for this species in West Africa. From other records, it appears to be common in many other parts of the world.
range: This species is almost ubiquitously found throughout the Atlantic and the Pacific Oceans. It is found in waters throughout the west African coast. It has an estimated depth distribution of zero to 5,000 m.
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures in place for the protection of this species.

rationale: Diaphus hudsoni is a widespread, common species that is not facing any known threats. Further research on this species needs to be conducted to assess the life history, population size and trend in the eastern Atlantic. This species is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This species is oceanic, mesopelagic and is typically found in depths below 250 m. Spawning takes place in the summer (Hulley and Paxton in press). Some data on larval development of this species in the Benguela region and off Easter Island are available (Olivar 1987, Acuña and Cabrera 2007).
threats: There are no known threats for this species, and it is not under pressure from fisheries.
population: There is little information regarding the actual population size of this species, however, it has been reported to accumulate in densities of up to 5.6 tonnes/km2, estimated at the shelf-break off the west coast of South Africa (Hulley and Paxton in press). This species is considered common throughout its range, as indicated by mesopelagic trawl surveys (Kobyliansky et al. 2010).
range: This species can be found in the area of the Benguela upwelling region, with isolates farther offshore to 02°W. It is also found circumglobally in the region of the southern Subtropical Convergence (33°S–52°S), with northern extensions in eastern boundary currents (Hulley and Paxton in press).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. Its distribution overlaps with some marine protected areas in parts of its range (WDPA 2010).

rationale: This species is widespread and there are no threats that can be identified. Further research on this species needs to be conducted to assess the life history, population size and trend in the Atlantic. With no known threats, this species is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This species is oceanic, mesopelagic and performs diel migrations from deeper waters up to less than 100 m (juveniles) or below 160 m (adults) during the night for feeding purposes (Hulley and Paxton in press).
threats: There are no known threats for this species, and it is not under pressure from fisheries.
population: There are little data regarding the population size and stability of this species in the eastern Atlantic.
range: This species circumglobal in the southern subtropical convergence 33°S to 58°S. In the eastern Atlantic, this species is found from Namibia and South Africa (Bianchi et al. 1999).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. Its distribution overlaps with some marine protected areas in parts of its range (World Database on Protected Areas 2010).

rationale: Lampanyctus australis is a widespread species that is not facing any known threats. More research on this species needs to be conducted to assess the population size and trend in the eastern Atlantic. This species is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This species is oceanic, mesopelagic and performs diel migrations from below 500 m during the day, up to 100 m during the night for feeding purposes. Spawning probably takes place in the winter (Hulley and Paxton in press).
threats: There are no known threats for this species, and it is not under pressure from fisheries.
population: There are little data regarding the population size  of this species in the eastern Atlantic, though it appears to be common off the southwest coast of South Africa (Rubies 1985) and catch rates in the South Atlantic (0.12g/1,000m3) and Indian Oceans (0.15g/1,000m3) have been assessed (P.A. Hulley pers. comm. 2013).
range: In the eastern Atlantic, this species is found in the Benguela Upwelling region, with isolates farther offshore (17.99°S, 4.45°E) in the eastern South Atlantic. It is also found circumglobally in the region of the southern Subtropical Convergence (28°S–56°S; Hulley and Paxton in press). There are isolates in the southeastern Atlantic reach up to 16° S.
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. Its distribution overlaps with some marine protected areas in parts of its range (World Database on Protected Areas 2010).

rationale: Lampanyctus intricarius is a widespread species that is not facing any known threats. More research on this species needs to be conducted to assess the population size and trend in the eastern Atlantic. This species is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This species is oceanic, mesopelagic and performs diel migrations from as deep as 550-750 m during the day, up to 40-550 m during the night for feeding purposes (Hulley and Paxton in press).
threats: There are no known threats for this species, and it is not under pressure from fisheries.
population: There are little data regarding the population size of this species in the eastern Atlantic, however it appears to be fairly common in other parts of its range, such as off southern Tasmania (Williams and Koslow 1997). It is well represented in museum collections.
range: In the eastern Atlantic, this species can be found in the Mauritanian and Benguela upwelling regions, isolates north to 14°S in southeastern sector. It is also known from the western North Atlantic 32°N-40°N, circumglobally in region of southern Subtropical Convergence 30°S-55°S, with northern extensions to 18°S in eastern boundary currents.
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. Its distribution overlaps with some marine protected areas in parts of its range (World Database on Protected Areas 2010).

rationale: This widely distributed, deep-living species can be abundant in part of its range. There are no known major threats; therefore, it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This mesopelagic species has a maximum standard length of 11.5 cm (Robertson and Clements 2015).
threats: There are no known major threats.
population: According to records, this species occurs commonly but in relatively low abundance in parts of its range. It is abundant in the Agulhas region (Hulley 1984, Olivar and Beckley 1994).
range: This species is distributed in the southern subtropical convergence zone of the Atlantic, Indian and southwestern Pacific to New Zealand (Robertson and Clements 2015, FishNet2 and OZCAM databases accessed June 2018). Its depth range is 400-775 metres (A. Williams pers. comm. 2018).
useTrade: Many myctophids have high wax ester or lipid content (Catul et al. 2011), and therefore have low palatability for human consumption and are not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures.

rationale: Lampichthys procerus is a widespread species that is not facing any known threats. More research on this species needs to be conducted to assess the population size and trend in the eastern Atlantic. This species as Least Concern.
habitat: This species is oceanic, mesopelagic and performs diel migrations from as deep as 700-1,200 m during the day, up to 100-700 m during the night for feeding purposes.
threats: There are no known threats for this species, and it is not under pressure from fisheries.
population: There are little data regarding the population size and stability of this species in the eastern Atlantic. However, it appears to be common in other parts of its range, such as off southern Tasmania (Williams and Koslow 1997).
range:
In the eastern Atlantic, this species is found south of 23°S. It is found in all three oceans. Two isolated records from south of Cape Lopez (00.60°S, 08.75°E) and west of Mayumba (0.38°S, 10.63°E) are questionable (Hulley and Paxton in press).
Elsewhere, this species is circumglobal in the southern hemisphere in the region of the Subtropical Convergence but with extensions into lower latitudes in eastern boundary currents. In the Southern Ocean, known from 45°10'S, 69°12'E (Hulley 1990). On the east coast of South America, this species is found between 31°S and 44°S (Figueiredo et al. 2002).
useTrade: This species is not commercially exploited.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. Its distribution overlaps with some marine protected areas in parts of its range (World Database on Protected Areas 2010).

rationale: Nannobrachium atrum is a widespread species that is not facing any known threats. More research on this species needs to be conducted to assess the population size and trend in the eastern Atlantic. This species is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This species is oceanic, mesopelagic and performs diel migrations from as deep as 550-850 m during the day, up to 60-850 m during the night for feeding purposes. Spawning primarily takes place in autumn (Hulley and Paxton in press).
threats: There are no known threats for this species, and it is not under pressure from fisheries.
population: There are little data regarding its population size and stability in the eastern Atlantic. It appears in moderate numbers in trawl surveys conducted around the Mid-Atlantic and Walvis ridges (Kobylianksy et al. 2010), as well as the Canary Islands (Wienerroither et al. 2009).
range: In the eastern Atlantic, this species has a disjunct distribution between 36°N-15°N and between 14°S-46°S. In the western Atlantic, this species can be found from 25°N–42°N, as well as the Gulf of Mexico. It can also be found in the Indian ocean and the western Pacific. This species has also been described from off southern Greenland, Iceland, the Faroe Islands and northern Great Britain.
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. Its distribution overlaps with some marine protected areas in parts of its range (World Database on Protected Areas 2010).

rationale: Symbolophorus boops is a widespread species that is not facing any known threats. More research on this species needs to be conducted to assess the population size and trend in the eastern Atlantic.This species is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This species is oceanic, mesopelagic and performs diel migrations from as deep as 225-450 m during the day, up to 10-280 m during the night for feeding purposes. Spawning takes place in the summer (Hulley and Paxton in press).
threats: There are no known threats for this species, and it is not under pressure from fisheries.
population: This species is well represented in southern hemisphere museum collections. It is reported to accumulate in great numbers off the shelf break of western South Africa. It is generally common in the Benguela Upwelling region and the Agulhas current system (Rubies 1984). At the Benguela shelf break there have been biomass estimates of up to 33 tonnes/km<sup>2</sup> (P.A. Hulley pers. comm.) and it is considered a potential for commercial fisheries.
range: This species occurs sporadically in the area north of northern Namibia and in the Benguela Upwelling region. It is also circumglobal in temperate waters from 30°S–52°S, with a northern extension to 18°S in the eastern south Atlantic (Hulley and Paxton in press).
useTrade: This species is not commercially exploited, but catch rates of about 32 tonnes/hour are estimated at the shelf-break off the west coast of South Africa (Hulley and Paxton in press).
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. Its distribution overlaps with some marine protected areas in parts of its range (World Database on Protected Areas 2010).

rationale: Brama brama is circumglobally distributed and there may be some confusion pertaining to the taxonomy. It is a pelagic offshore species that is an important prey item to large marine predators. It is a large species that is relatively long-lived and therefore may be vulnerable to overfishing. It commonly occurs as bycatch in longline fisheries where it is commercially valuable and has seen some evidence of overfishing off the Spanish coast, however the overall level of this threat is unknown. Brama brama is included in Annex I of the 1982 Convention on the Law of the Sea created by the United Nations Convention of the Law of the Sea (UNCLOS) because it is highly migratory. Brama brama is not commercially fished in the Caribbean, however, there is interest by the fisheries. Brama brama is caught as bycatch of longlines and driftnets. It is not commercially exploited off the West African coast. This species is listed as Least Concern.
habitat:
Brama brama is oceanic (Briggs 1960, Richards 2006) and it is found in small schools on the continental slope. Brama brama embark on vertical migrations daily (Haedrich 1986, Dulcic 1999, Lobo and Erzini 2001) and exercises diel migration where it migrates to shallower depth at night (Rodriguez 1980). Seasonal migrations have been linked to water temperature (Kells and Carpenter 2011). Its diet consists of myctophids, other small bony fishes and invertebrates (Bianchi et al. 1999, Kells and Carpenter 2011). The maximum total length (TL) is 101 cm (Claro 1994). Paul et al. (2004) estimated B. brama longevity to be at least 25 years. Brama brama is oviparous with planktonic eggs and larvae and spawns in the summer months (Richards 2006). 

Vakily et al. (2002) describes B. brama as benthopelagic with a maximum size of 100 cm TL off of West Africa. It is an important prey item for large pelagic predators such as dolphin, sharks, and tunas (Dunn et al. 2010, Hassani et al. 1997). In the Mediterranean, B. brama spawning season occurs in August and September, but is later in the Eastern Atlantic (Haedrich 1986, Dulcic 1999).

Bramids are epi- and mesopelagic fishes found throughout temperate and warm-temperate oceans that feed on small fishes and macroinvertebrates including squid. They are year-round batch spawners that undergo significant morphological changes with growth (Haedrich in press).
threats: In the Caribbean, Brama brama is caught as bycatch of longlines (Garcia 1994) and driftnets (Daniela et al. 2010). There is interest in B. brama by fisheries in the Western Central Atlantic. In the Eastern Central Atlantic, Brama brama occurs frequently in the Spanish deepwater bottom-longline hake fishery off Mauritania where it is retained and sold (Ramos et al. 2001). It is large and relatively long-lived and therefore may be vulnerable to overfishing (Rodriguez 1980, Iwamoto pers. comm. 2013). The level of this threat is unknown at this time (Iwamoto pers. comm. 2013). Brama brama is an important commercial fishery in the Eastern Central Atlantic, Northeast Atlantic, Southeast Atlantic, Antarctic/Indian Ocean, Mediterranean Sea and Southwest Pacific.
population:
Despite the wide distribution, population information is limited for the Western Central Atlantic. Between 1881 to 2007, 70 B. brama were deposited in museum collections globally. There are no substantial threats outside the region that will significantly affect syvpopulations in the Caribbean through immigration or emigration.

In the Eastern Central Atlantic, Brama brama commonly occurs in trawl catches on the outer continental shelf as well as longlines off of Portugal and the Atlantic coast of Spain (Heemstra and Heemstra 2004). In a longline survey off of the Cape Verde Islands, one individual of this species was caught between 700-750 m depth (Menezes et al. 2004). It commonly occurred in a survey over the continental slope off Namibia where it was more common during cooler summers versus warmer ones (MacPherson and Gordoa 1992). Two individuals were captured in a survey near the border between Western Sahara and Mauritania (Merrett and Marshall 1981). This species occurs frequently in the Spanish deepwater bottom-longline hake fishery off Mauritania where it is retained and sold (Ramos et al. 2001). There appears to be evidence for migration between subpopulations (Rodriguez 1980).
range:
Brama brama is distributed worldwide (Atlantic, Indian and South Pacific) in tropical to warm temperate waters (Thompson 2002). It is widely distributed in the epipelagic and mesopelagic zones of the North Atlantic and possibly the Southern Ocean above 30°N and 35°S. Richards (2006) noted B. brama young to be found from Florida to the Mediterranean.

In the Western Atlantic, B. brama is known from a few scattered records from Nova Scotia, Bermuda, Gulf of Mexico, northern South America (Robertson and Acero pers. comm. 2013) to Belize and the Antilles (Claro 1994). It is distributed in the western Atlantic from zero to 400 m depth from south of Cape Cod (39°58'N, 70°46'W) to the Grand Banks and south to northern South America (Moore et al. 2003).

In the Eastern Atlantic, B. brama occurs from central Norway to Algoa Bay, South Africa. Off of the west African coast it ranges from Morocco (30°N) to the north and from South Africa (35°S) to to the south (Haedrich in press). Off of the African coast this species ranges from Walvis Bay, Namibia south around the Cape of Good Hope to Algoa Bay, South Africa in depths from 50-1,000 m where it rarely occurs near land (Heemstra and Heemstra 2004). In a longline survey off of the Cape Verde Islands, one individual of this species was caught between 700-750 m depth (Menezes et al. 2004). This species has been captured in trawls off Western Sahara and Mauritania (Merrett and Marshall 1981, Ramos et al. 2001).

It is found from shallow waters to 1,000 m depth (Kells and Carpenter 2011).
useTrade:
While Brama brama is not commercially exploited by the Western Central Atlantic fisheries, there is interest in this species by the fisheries.

In the Eastern Central Atlantic, Brama brama commonly occurs in trawl catches on the outer continental shelf as well as longlines off of Portugal and the Atlantic coast of Spain (Heemstra and Heemstra 2004). Several species of the Bramidae family are caught as bycatch by longline and vertical line off of Africa. They are generally considered a highly desirable foodfish. A commercial fishery for Brama species exists off of the northern Iberian Peninsula (Haedrich in press). This species is also caught as bycatch in the midwater trawl fishery (zero to 1,000 m depth) off of Walvis Bay, South Africa (Bianchi et al. 1999). It occurs as bycatch in the deepwater longline fishery for European Hake off of southern Portugal where it is retained and sold (Erzini et al. 2001). This species occurs frequently in the Spanish deepwater bottom-longline hake fishery off Mauritania where it is retained and sold (Ramos et al. 2001). Catches were reportedly high for this species off the Spanish coast between 1953-1960, low between 1960-1965, increased between 1965-1969, and 1969 was followed by an apparent disappearance until 1976 (Rodriguez 1980). This species frequently occurs as bycatch in the drift net fishery for Albacore in the eastern North Atlantic (Rogan and Mackey 2007). This species is not commercially exploited in the Cape Verde Islands (Monteiro pers. comm. 2013), off Mauritania (Camara pers. comm. 2013) or off Nigeria (Williams pers. comm. 2013).
conservationActions: Brama brama is a highly migratory species that is included in Annex I of the 1982 Convention on the Law of the Sea created by the United Nations Convention of the Law of the Sea (UNCLOS). Responsibility is given to coastal states to determine the proper management and use of fishery resources within their national jurisdiction. Under Annex I, coastal states and other states that fish where there is a presence of highly migratory species are to ensure the conservation and optimum utilization of listed species (Garcia 1994, Malak et al. 2011). In the Eastern Central Atlantic, there are no known conservation measures in place for Brama brama.

rationale: Arctozenus risso is a wide-ranging species, is not utilized and has no known major threats. Therefore, A. risso is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: Arctozenus risso is oceanic, epipelagic to bathypelagic, and feeds on fishes and shrimps. It occurs singly or in small schools (Post 1984). It is hermaphroditic and oviparous with planktonic larvae (Richards 2006). It spawns at continental slopes and oceanic banks (Cherel and Duhamel 2003). The maximum total length (TL) is 31 cm (Thompson 2002).
threats: There are no known major threats to Arctozenus risso. However, it is caught as bycatch in deep-water fisheries in some areas.
population: Population information is very limited for Arctozenus risso.
range: This species occurs from the Arctic to Antarctic. In the northeastern Pacific, it is found from British Columbia, Canada south to Guadalupe Island, Mexico. In the southeastern Pacific, it occurs in Chile. In the western Atlantic, it occurs from Newfoundland and Labrador, Canada south to Georgia, Florida, the Bahamas, and the Lesser Antilles (Richards 2006). Specifically in the Greater Caribbean, it occurs from southeastern Florida, Northwest Providence Channel (the Bahamas) and the Lesser Antilles. In the eastern Atlantic, it is known from Norway to Portugal. In the northwestern Pacific, it occurs in Iwate, Japan south to the Philippines. In the southwestern Pacific, it is known from New South Wales, Australia to Tasmania (Distribution inferred from records of A. risso on Fishnet2.net, 2012). It is found at depths between zero to 2,000 m (Richards 2006).
useTrade: Arctozenus risso is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for Arctozenus risso.

rationale: This species is circum-globally distributed. There is no use and trade information available for this species. There are no species-specific threats to this species and no conservation measures are currently in place. Therefore, this species is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: Aristostomias polydactylus has night-time centres of abundance between zero to 300 m and 700-800 m, and has daytime centres of abundance between 300-700 m (Sutton and Hopkins 1996).
threats: There are no known species-specific threats to Aristostomias polydactylus.
population: It is not known whether there is substantial immigration/emigration from outside the Eastern Central Atlantic that will significantly affect subpopulations in the region. It has been shown that members of this genus can be rare in the Atlantic Ocean (Kenaley 2008).
range: Aristostomias polydactylus is a circumglobal species, found at depths of zero to 800 m (Sutton and Hopkins 1996). Off of Africa, it has been recorded from both the Atlantic Ocean and Indian Ocean (Goodyear and Gibbs 1986). There are few occurrences of this species within the Eastern Central Atlantic.
useTrade: There is currently no use and/or trade information regarding Aristostomias polydactylus.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for Aristostomias polydactylus. More research is needed regarding the population status and trend.

rationale: This widely distributed, deep-living species has no known major threats; therefore, it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This mesopelagic species has a maximum standard length of 15 cm (Kenaley and Stewart 2015, Harold 2016).
threats: There are no known major threats.
population: Population data are limited for this species. There are 37 occurrence records of this species with each lot containing between 1-7 individuals in the FishNet2 database (accessed September 2018).
range: This species is circumglobally distributed in the Southern Hemisphere Subtropical Convergence between 30°S to 45°S (Kenaley et al. 2008, Kenaley and Stewart 2015, Harold 2016). In the Atlantic, it is known from Namibia to South Africa and from Brazil to Argentina (Gibbs and Barnett 1990). In the Pacific, it is known from southern Australia, New Zealand and Chile (Pequeño 1989, Gomon et al. 1994, Hoese et al. 2006, Kenaley and Stewart et al. 2015). Specimens have been taken at depths between 0-700 metres (Kenaley and Stewart 2015).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures.

rationale: Borostomias antarcticus is found in the temperate to polar waters of the North Atlantic and the southern hemisphere. This species was commercially harvested in 2010, in which one tonne was collected. However, the nature of this harvest needs to be determined. It is assumed to have been bycatch and not thought to be utilized. The commercial value should be determined. There are no species-specific threats to this species at present. There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. Therefore, this species is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: Borostomias antarcticus is a meso- to bathypelagic (Moore et al. 2003) and bathydemersal species, occurring at depths of 300-2,630 m (Gon 1990) in temperate to polar waters (Pakhomov et al 2006). It feeds almost exclusively on fish and copepods (Klimpel et al. 2006).
threats: There are currently no known threats to Borostomias antarcticus. However, over-exploitation may become a threat, pending the determination of its commercial value. More research is needed to determine if B. antarcticus faces any threats.
population: There is no population information.
range: Borostomias antarcticus is found in the temperate to polar waters of the North Atlantic and the southern hemisphere. In the western North Atlantic, B. antarcticus is found from 39°N northwards to off Greenland and Iceland (Moore et al. 2003). It has been recorded from the Prince Edward Islands, a sub-Arctic archipelago approximately 2,000 km southeast off the South African coast (Pakhomov et al. 2006), King George Island (South Shetland Islands, Antarctica) (Pusch et al. 2004), the Bay of Biscay (Klimpel et al. 2006) and the Mediterranean Sea (Moranta et al. 2004). In Africa, B. antarcticus is known only from Atlantic waters up to 18°S (Gibbs 1986). This species is poorly represented in the Eastern Central Atlantic with one record off northern Angola and one in the western Eastern Central Atlantic (OBIS 2014).
useTrade: In 2010, the catch total recorded for Borostomias antarcticus in the western Indian Ocean was approximately one tonne. However, this species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are currently no species-specific conservation measures in place for Borostomias antarcticus. More research is needed regarding its current population size and trend, habitats, ecology, life history, use/trade and threats.

rationale: This species is circum-globally distributed. There is no use and trade information available for this species. This species is caught as bycatch in several fisheries; however, this is not a major threat. There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. Therefore, this species is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: The diet of Chauliodus sloani seems to consist only of fishes (Appelbaum 1982) and it feeds mainly on myctophids (Scott and Scott 1988). It is a prey item of the commercially important Orange Roughy (Williams et al. 2001). The maximum standard length 35.0 cm (SL; Masuda et al. 1984). It is oviparous (Scott and Scott 1988).
threats: This species is caught as bycatch of deep-sea shrimp trawlers off the southwest coast of India (Pillai et al. 2009). Chauliodus sloani is also sometimes caught as bycatch in the Chilean crustacean trawl fishery (Queirolo et al. 2011). In the Balearic Islands in the western Mediterranean, C. sloani is caught as bycatch and discarded from deep-sea crustacean fisheries (Moranta et al. 2000).
population: There is no population information.
range:
This fish has a circumglobal range. It mainly occurs in warm and temperate areas, but with several distribution gaps in the southern central Atlantic, northern Indian Ocean, eastern Pacific north of the equator, western Mediterranean, South China Sea and East China Sea (Jawad et al. 2013). It is also found on the western Gulf of Mexico (Sutton and Hopkins 1996), north central Gulf of Mexico (Ross et al. 2010), the coast of Somalia (Butler et al. 2001), western Mediterranean (Whitehead et al. 1984), Sedlo Seamount in the northeast central Atlantic Ocean (Menezes et al. 2012) and Columbian Caribbean Sea (Paramo et al. 2012). One specimen was observed during a remotely operated underwater vehicle (ROV) dive off of Grand Banks, Newfoundland (Baker et al. 2012). It can also be found North Carolina and Virginia continental slopes (Gartner et al. 2008), the Scotian Shelf off of Canada (Shackell and Frank 2003), Arabian Sea coasts of Oman (Jawad et al. 2013), South China Sea (Randall and Lim 2000), around Guam and the Northern Mariana Islands (Suntsov and Domokos 2013) and the southern coast of Tasmania (Williams et al. 2001).

This species is bathypelagic, with a depth range of 200-4,700 m (Yang et al. 1996). It is most commonly found at 494-1,000 m (Shinohara et al. 1994). In the Ionian Sea, the species occurs at depths of  473-1,192 m (Mytilineou et al. 2005). In the Sargasso Sea, the species is found at around 1,000 m depth (Sutton et al. 2010). In the Columbian Caribbean Sea it is found at depths from 396-430 m (Paramo et al. 2012).
useTrade: Chauliodus sloani is not currently utilized as a commercial species.
conservationActions: There are currently no active efforts to conserve or protect this species.

rationale: Idiacanthus atlanticus is a circumglobal species, inhabiting the subtropical to temperate waters in the southern hemisphere only. There is no use and trade information available for this species. There are no species-specific threats to this species. There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. Therefore, this species is listed as Least Concern.
habitat:
Idiacanthus atlanticus is a mesopelagic (Hoese et al. 2006). 

The diet of Idiacanthus species consists mainly of fishes (Harold 1999). There is distinct sexual dimorphism within this species. Females are solid black, with well developed canine teeth, a barbel and pelvic fins with six stripes. Males, on the other hand, are dark-brown, have no teeth on maxilla, with only a few teeth present on the vomer and palatine (Harold 1999) and neither a barbel nor pelvic fins (Figueiredo et al. 2002). Males only reach approximately 15% of the females' size and retain some larval features (Figueiredo et al. 2002). Males reach 5 cm (SL), while females reach 35 cm (SL) in standard length (Hulley 1986). Females have pelvic fins while males do not (Harold 1999). In males, the anterior anal-fin rays have been modified as intromittent organ (Hulley 1986, Harold 1999).

Females live below 500 m during the day and perform vertical migration at night to shallower depths. However, males are always found in deep water, usually at least 1,000-2,000 m (Gon 1990).

In a study conducted on the southern Patagonian shelf, from approximately 46-56°S, Idiacanthus atlanticus was found by trawl in depths of 500 m or less, indicating that the larvae of this species inhabits waters much shallower than adults of this species (Ehrlich et al. 1999).
threats: There do not appear to be any threats towards this species.
population:
There are 182 lots of this specimen worldwide in 134 geocodes. A total of 16 individuals were taken in a single collection, which is the most individual in one lot on record (Fishnet2 2013).

In a trawl sample taken in 2001 around the vicinity of Prince Edward Island, there was a relatively high occurrence frequency percentage of I. atlanticus at 11.5%, the third highest in the area (Pakhomav et al. 2006).
range: Idiacanthus atlanticus is a circumglobal species, inhabiting the subtropical to temperate waters in the southern hemisphere only, probably limited by the subtropical convergence. It is incidentally found in sub-Antarctic waters of the Southern Ocean, but not often (Krueger 1990).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no known conservation measures in place for this species.

rationale: Idiacanthus fasciola is a subtropical species, circumglobally distributed, except in the east Pacific. There is no use and trade information available for this species. This species is not utilized and there are no species-specific threats to this species. There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. Therefore, this species is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: Idiacanthus fasciola is a mesopelagic species (Kreuger 1990). Its diet consists mainly of other fish (Harold 1999). There is marked sexual dimorphism within this species. The males reach about 15% of the female body size (Hulley 1986). Males reach 4 cm, while females reach 35 cm in length (Harold in press). Females undergo diel, vertical migrations, while the males remain in the deeper stratum of the water (Sutton and Hopkins 1996).
threats: There do not appear to be any threats for this species.
population: There are 571 records of this species worldwide in 523 geocodes. The largest single lot size is 18, hauled in 1981 near Papua New Guinea (Fishnet2 2012). In a trawl survey conducted along the mid Atlantic Ridge between the years 1975 and 1978, the relative abundance of I. fasciola that was found was relatively low at 0.3% in comparison with other fish collected in the study (Gushchin and Kukuyev 1981).
range: ]Idiacanthus fasciola is a subtropical species, circumglobally distributed, except in the east Pacific (Harold in press). This species is found in the waters of the North Atlantic, north of 10°N and into the South Atlantic, from the southern tip of Africa to the waters off the Patagonian region of Argentina (Nakamura et al. 1986). In the Indo-Pacific, it is found across the Indian Ocean and north of about 23°S to west and central Pacific between 27°N and 43°S. This species is also found in the South China Sea and in waters near the Taiwan Province (Yang et al. 1996) and Japan. Idiacanthus fasciola inhabits waters between the depths of 500 m (Krueger 1990) and 2000 m (Mundy 2005).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are currently no conservation measures in place for this species.

rationale: This widely distributed, deep-living species has no known major threats; therefore, it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This is a meso- to bathypelagic species. Juveniles are often found at shallower depths than adults (Kenaley and Stewart 2015). The largest specimen measured 26 cm standard length (Harold 2016). This species may be a vertical migrator (T. Harold and R. Milligan pers. comm. 2018).
threats: There are no known major threats.
population: This species is reported to be common in New Zealand (Kenaley and Stewart 2015).
range: This species is often associated with the subtropical to temperate waters of the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans (Kenaley and Stewart 2015) and with the southern Subtropical Convergence Zone (Harold 2016). In the eastern Indian Ocean, it is known from western Australia (Paxton et al. 1989, Gomon et al. 1994). In the southwest Pacific, it occurs off southern Australia and New Zealand (Paulin et al. 1989, Kenaley and Stewart 2015). In the southern Atlantic, it occurs from Namibia to South Africa, off Brazil and between 20° and 50°S; it is known from the same geo-typical coordinates in the Pacific (Figueiredo et al. 2002). Specimens have been taken at depths between 50-1,220 metres (Kenaley and Stewart 2015).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures.

rationale: This widely distributed, deep-living species is common and abundant in parts of its range. There are no known major threats; therefore, it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: This species is meso- to benthopelagic (Kenaley and Stewart 2015). It lives a largely pelagic existence until attaining a larger size class, when it settles to the benthos (Kenaley and Stewart 2015). Adults may be exclusively benthopelagic (Harold 2002). The largest specimen measured 66 cm standard length (Kenaley and Stewart 2015).
threats: There are no known major threats.
population: This is one of the most frequently encountered species in New Zealand waters within the subfamily Melanostomiinae (Kenaley and Stewart 2015), and it has also been described as relatively abundant in the waters off Uruguay and Argentina (Krefft 1976).
range: This species is circumglobally distributed in the subtropical waters of the southern hemisphere (Gibbs 1986). It has been reported from the southern Atlantic, Indian and Pacific Oceans south of 30°S (Gibbs 1986, Paxton et al. 1989, Pequeño 1989, Meléndez 1999, Trunov 1999, Hutchins 2001, Kenaley and Stewart 2015). Specimens have been taken at depths between 30-2,000 metres, but it is most often found below 500 m (Kenaley and Stewart 2015); although, the collection data available appears to indicate it occurs mainly from 500-1,200 m (T. Harold and R. Milligan pers. comm. 2018).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures.

rationale: Stomias boa occurs in the North Atlantic Ocean, the Mediterranean, and is circumglobal in the southern hemisphere. It occurs in subtropical to temperate waters. There is no use and trade information available for this species. There are no species-specific threats to this species. There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. Therefore, this species is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: The maximum size for this species is 32 cm. Based on general information on the subfamily Stomiinae, the diet probably consists mainly of other mesopelagic fishes and some crustaceans (Harold in press).
threats: Current threats to Stomais boa are unknown.
population: This species is well represented in museum collections with 1,360 records (Fishnet2 Portal 2013).
range: Stomias boa occurs in the North Atlantic Ocean, the Mediterranean and is circumglobal in the southern hemisphere. It occurs in subtropical to temperate waters (Harold in press). The depth range for this species is 200 to 1,500 m (Gon 1990).
useTrade: Use and trade information is not available for this species.
conservationActions: There are no species specific conservation efforts in place for Stomias boa. However, the distribution for this species overlaps with a number of marine protected areas (IUCN and UNEP-WCMC 2014).

rationale: Stomias longibarbatus is a circumglobal species that occurs from equatorial to subtropical zones. There is no use and trade information available for this species. There are no species-specific threats to this species. There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. Therefore, this species is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: The maximum standard length (SL) for this species is 43.0 cm (Bigelow et al. 1964). Based on general information on the subfamily Stomiinae, the diet probably consists mainly of other mesopelagic fishes and some crustaceans (Harold 2002).
threats: Current threats to Stomias longibarbatus are unknown.
population: There are 84 museum records for this species (Fishnet2 Portal 2013).
range: Stomias longibarbatus is a circumglobal species that occurs from equatorial to subtropical zones (Harold in press). The depth range for this species is 400 to 1,463 m (Mundy 2005).
useTrade: Use and trade information is not available for this species.
conservationActions: There are no species specific conservation efforts in place for Stomias longibarbatus. However, the distribution for this species overlaps with a number of marine protected areas (IUCN and UNEP-WCMC 2014).

rationale: Anoplogaster cornuta is a circumglobally distributed, deep-dwelling, uncommon species with no known threats. It is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: Anoplogaster cornuta is a deep-sea species that inhabits the mesopelagic and bathypelagic zones. It has a maximum size of 16 cm SL. Juveniles feed on crustaceans, while adults feed on fishes. This species may swim in small groups at times (Moore in press). Off of Hawaii, this species is found between 135 m to 980 m depth at night and migrates to deeper water between 650 m to 2,915 m during the day (Mundy 2005).
